data.text: Adding Aero Bars to a Flat Bar: Any Experience?

I added aero bars to my Surly to give additional body positions on long day rides. I got something called a Fred Bar to raise the aerobar above the handlebar to ease the strain on the back. data.text: The disadvantage of that setup is that steering is much more lively. Not ideal if you are belting down a steep hill fully loaded. I use bar end add-ons that curve down. Way more stable, and I can drop down when headed into a wind. Buena suerte.

data.text: me too. I have them inboard at 40cm apart which is the same as the hoods on my road bike. Gives me not only different hand but also different arm position.

data.text: I added to my road bike for the same reasons. The aero bars I chose did not allow my hands below the arm rest and I wish they did. That’s the only thing I wish I would have done different. Otherwise I’m happy with them.

data.text: I added them to a bike a few years ago for long rides. You have to be extra careful because when "things" pop up suddenly you have less control, but for long rides on the road it's nice to be able to move your arms and save the wrists.

data.author: Mike Micho

data.text: I added extensions to the flat bars, but realize I really need something to relieve me from leaning on my hands and wrists. Eventually will switch to bike with more upright position or some sort of recumbent.
data.author: Elizabeth Planteen

data.text: when you get a recumbent you will wish you had one sooner. The only part of me that is worn out after a long ride is the leg muscles , just no pain anywhere else.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: Road bikes are not designed to be ridden with your elbows on the handlebar. It's a bad riding posture and will create problems in the hips. Not to mention you will have to lift your chin to see the road and that'll add strain to your neck and shoulder. It'll also add time to reach for the brakes. Aerobars are for tri bikes whose down tubes are more vertical and you're not supposed to brake too often, if at all.
